questions.text: The clotting factor that is reduced in pregnancy is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor 11 The clotting factor that is reduced in pregnancy is D. Factor 11.

Highyeild:

Factor XI (FXI) deficiency is associated with highly variable bleeding, including excessive gynecologic and obstetrical bleeding. Since approximately 20% of FXI-deficient women will experience pregnancy-related bleeding, careful planning and knowledge of appropriate hemostatic management is pivotal for their care. Factor Change in Pregnancy II Unchanged VII and Fibrinogen Increased VIII, IX, X, XII Increased XI Reduced Protein S Reduced Protein C and AT-III Unchanged Plasminogen Increased D-Dimer Increased

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A - Option B - Option C - Factor IX (FIX, Christmas factor) is a blood clotting factor, a zymogen of serine protease. Upon activation, FIX is converted into the active serine protease and, in the presence of Ca 2+ and membrane phospholipids, it hydrolyses one arginine-isoleucine bond in factor X to form the activated factor X

Extraedge:

Pregnancy is a procoagulable state as a physiologically adaptive mechanism to prevent post-partum bleeding. In non-pregnant women: Plasma fibrinogen averages 300 mg/dL (200-400 mg/dL) In Normal pregnancy plasma fibrinogen concentration increases 50% There is also a decrease in the anticoagulant mechanisms, such as resistance to activated protein C and decreased levels of protein S. In addition, the increased uterine pressure slows down the venous return into the heart, making the blood more likely to clot.

questions.text: Which among the following leads to detachment of Myosin head from Actin?

options.label: B
options.text: Attachment of ATP on Myosin Head

questions.correct_answer: B. Attachment of ATP on Myosin Head
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Attachment of ATP on Myosin Head The detachment of the myosin head from actin occurs when ATP (adenosine triphosphate) binds to the myosin head.

Highyeild:

Each Myosin: 2 heavy chains + 4 light chains Head Of myosin has ATPase enzyme The motion of muscle shortening occurs as myosin heads bind to actin and pull the actin inwards. This action requires energy, which is provided by ATP. Myosin binds to actin at a binding site on the globular actin protein. Myosin has another binding site for ATP at which enzymatic activity hydrolyzes ATP to ADP, releasing an inorganic phosphate molecule and energy. ATP binding causes myosin to release actin, allowing actin and myosin to detach from each other. After this happens, the newly bound ATP is converted to ADP and inorganic phosphate, P i . The enzyme at the binding site on myosin is called ATPase. The energy released during ATP hydrolysis changes the angle of the myosin head into a “cocked” position. The myosin head is then in a position for further movement, possessing potential energy, but ADP and P i are still attached. If actin binding sites are covered and unavailable, the myosin will remain in the high energy configuration with ATP hydrolyzed, but still attached. If the actin binding sites are uncovered, a cross-bridge will form; that is, the myosin head spans the distance between the actin and myosin molecules. P i is then released, allowing myosin to expend the stored energy as a conformational change. The myosin head moves toward the M line, pulling the actin along with it. As the actin is pulled, the filaments move approximately 10 nm toward the M line. This movement is called the power stroke, as it is the step at which force is produced. During contraction: Actin –Myosin interaction takes place (attachment of ADP on Myosin head). During relaxation: Myosin head detached from Actin (attachment of ATP on Myosin head).

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A - Release of ADP and Pi - this occurs for releasing the stored energy in myosin head in the form of a conformational change - and so power stroke is generated. Option C - Attachment of ATP on Actin - ATP is attached at myosin and not actin. Option D - None of the above - this is not the correct option.

questions.text: Counter current mechanism seen in which of the following ? Skin Kidney Tests Intestines Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3,4 Counter current mechanism is seen in all 4 sites given, i.e., skin, kidney, testes and intestines. Statement: 1 and 3: In skin and testes, it helps in temperature regulation ( Countercurrent Heat Exchange ). Blood flowing from the core to the periphery (like the legs & feet) carries heat that can be readily lost through the skin . Similarly for testis, blood that returns from the testes through the plexuses is cooler than the blood in testicular arteries. The arterial blood is cooled by venous blood by a counter-current heat exchange mechanism. Statement: 4: In the Intestine it helps in better absorption of nutrients. Statement: 2: In the kidney it helps in maintaining the Hyperosmolarity of Medullary interstitium. The nephrons involved in the formation of concentrated urine extend all the way from the cortex of the kidney to the medulla and are accompanied by vasa recta.

Extraedge:

Key facts: descending LOH is water permeable, ascending LOH is NOT. Ascending LOH actively pumps out ions. water goes to where the most stuff is!!! Vasa recta removes . water so it doesn't dilute the medullary gradient.

options.label: B
options.text: Facilitated Diffusion- Ca2+ into Sarcoplasmic Reticulum

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Simple Diffusion -O2 Oxygen diffuses from alveoli into the pulmonary blood by simple diffusion.

Highyeild:

In simple diffusion, small non-polar molecules like oxygen (O2) can passively move across the cell membrane from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration without the need for any specific carrier proteins or energy expenditure.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Oxygen is lipid soluble, and it can pass through lipid bilayer, it does not need an ion channel, hence option D can be ruled out. Option B - this is not by facilitated diffusion - it is a primary active transport. Ca2+ into sarcoplasmic reticulum requires SERCA ( SarcoEndoplasmic Reticulum Calcium Transport ATPase). The pump is found in the membrane of the sarcoplasmic reticulum. In some cases, it is so plentiful that it may make up 90% of the protein there. Powered by ATP, it pumps calcium ions back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum , reducing the calcium level around the actin and myosin filaments and allowing the muscle to relax. Nervous stimulation leads to depolarization of the sarcolemma (muscle membrane) that triggers calcium ions' release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Option C - Glucose - secondary active transport facilitated by Sodium- Glucose transporter. So, this can be ruled out. Option D - ion channel transport - There are ion channels specific for K+, Na+, Ca2+, and Cl–, as well as channels that are nonselective for cations or anions. Each type of channel exists in multiple forms with diverse properties. Most are made up of identical or very similar sub units.

questions.text: Match the following transporters with the molecule they carry? Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1a, 2b, 3c, 4d Thyroxine is carried by thyroid-binding pre-albumin which is also known as transthyretin. Hemopexin binds with heme, particularly for heme recycling.

Highyeild:

Vitamin B12 binds to transcobalamin II in the ileal cells and is secreted into the plasma. Transcobalamin II delivers vitamin B12 to the liver and other cells of the body, including rapidly proliferating cells in the bone marrow and the gastrointestinal tract. Haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin and prevents its excretion in urine. Hemopexin binds to porphyrins, particularly heme, for heme recycling.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B - Haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin and prevents its excretion in urine. Hence, haptoglobin levels decrease in the presence of free hemoglobin as seen in hemolytic anemia. Option C - Transthyretin is prealbumin which carries the thyroid hormones (T4 and T3) in the blood and CSF. So it transports the thyroxine and retinol. Option D - Albumin is a carrier protein as well as an osmotic regulator which carries hormones, amino acids, vitamins and steroids too.

Extraedge:

Cells rely on “extracellular antioxidants,” i.e., the proteins in biological fluids to prevent such radical chemistry by sequestering the heme and its iron. Thus, haptoglobin (Hp) binds Hb, the source of heme that is bound by hemopexin (HPX), and transferrin binds iron. In plasma, HPX targets heme to the liver parenchymal cells for heme catabolism, iron storage, and re-distribution. In barrier tissues, HPX targets heme to brain neurons. Normally, HPX recycles after heme delivery whereas the Hp-Hb complex is degraded in macrophages.

questions.text: What will happen to the alveolar ventilation when pH is changed from 7.4 to 7.3 at PaO2 100 mmHg ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased Ventilation When the pH of the blood changes, it affects the body's acid-base balance, leading to respiratory compensation. Specifically, a decrease in pH (from 7.4 to 7.3 in this case) indicates a condition of acidosis, and the body will attempt to compensate for this by increasing ventilation.

Highyeild:

Decrease in pH leads to acidosis. Increase in arterial H+ ion stimulates peripheral chemoreceptors which respond to change in pH and result in increased alveolar ventilation to produce faster and deeper breathing (respiratory compensation). Breathing faster and deeper increases the amount of carbon dioxide exhaled, which raises the blood pH back toward normal.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B - Decreased Ventilation - this will in turn cause accumulation of CO2 and respiratory acidosis will develop. Option C - No change in Ventilation- this case of metabolic acidosis is to be compensated by respiratory changes. Option D - First decrease then increase - this is not the preferred method of compensation.

questions.text: Identify A and B in the following cell ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-K+B-Na+ Given is an image of Na-K ATPase pump. The Na+ K+ pump is an electrogenic transmembrane ATPase and situated in the outer plasma membrane of the cells; on the cytosolic side.

Highyeild:

The Na+ K+ ATPase pumps 3 Na+ out of the cell and 2K+ that into the cell, for every single ATP consumed. The plasma membrane is a lipid bilayer that arranged asymmetrically, containing cholesterol, phospholipids, glycolipids, sphingolipid, and proteins within the membrane. The Na+K+-ATPase pump helps to maintain osmotic equilibrium and membrane potential in cells. The sodium and potassium move against the concentration gradients. The Na+ K+-ATPase pump maintains the gradient of a higher concentration of sodium extracellularly and a higher level of potassium intracellularly. The sustained concentration gradient is crucial for physiological processes in many organs and has an ongoing role in stabilizing the resting membrane potential of the cell, regulating the cell volume, and cell signal transduction. It plays a crucial role on other physiological processes, such as maintenance of filtering waste products in the nephrons (kidneys), sperm motility, and production of the neuronal action potential Furthermore, the physiologic consequences of inhibiting the Na+-K+ ATPase are useful and the target in many pharmacologic applications. Na, K-ATPase is a crucial scaffolding protein that can interact with signalling proteins such as protein kinase C (PKC) and phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K).

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A - A-Na + B-K + - this is not the correct option as - Option B - A Ca 2+ B-Na + - The sodium-calcium exchanger (often denoted Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, exchange protein, or NCX) is an antiporter membrane protein that removes calcium from cells. Option D - A-Ca 2+ B-K + - no such physiological pump functional in our body.

questions.text: Which of the following act by increasing phospholipase C?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gq Gq is a type of G protein that activates phospholipase C (PLC). When a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) activates Gq, it promotes the activation of PLC, which in turn catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) to produce inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). These secondary messengers, IP3, and DAG, are involved in various cellular signaling pathways.

Highyeild:

GPCR is of 3 main types : Gs : Stimulates Adenylate cyclase, therefore act by increasing cAMP Gi Inhibits Adenylate cyclase therefore act by decreasing cAMP Gq : Activate Phosphatidylinositol phosphate(PIP) to inositol triphosphate (IP) and Diacylglycerol (DAG). This IP will increase Calcium. Go : It will decrease Calcium.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Gs: Gs is a type of G protein that activates adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in the production of cyclic AMP (cAMP) from ATP. It does not directly increase phospholipase C (PLC) activity. Option C. Gi: Gi is a type of inhibitory G protein that inhibits adenylate cyclase, leading to a decrease in cAMP levels. It does not directly increase phospholipase C (PLC) activity.

questions.text: Two vessels one with diameter D and length L. Another with diameter 2D and length 2L. The rate of flow in second will be how many times that of first?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

8 Times F= ΔP x π/8 x 1/ η x r4/L, where F = flow ΔP = pressure difference between two ends of the tube η= viscosity r = radius of the tube L = length of the tube Flow through B = (2*r) 4 /2L = 8 times

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A - flow is related to the 4 th power of radius and inversely related to length - so relation will be 8 times to the first. Option: B - this could only be the possible answer when there is no relation to the length in this specific case. Else when we are talking about 4 th power of radius , which opposes length by 1 power, 16 times can never be the correct answer. Option: C - 32 times also cannot be the correct answer, as explained for option B .

questions.text: Wrong one among the following about accommodation changes in high altitude ascent is ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Respiratory Acidosis The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation and not respiratory acidosis.

Highyeild:

Compensatory mechanisms that are carried out to increase altitude tolerance (acclimatization) include: Hyperventilation causing respiratory alkalosis and shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left (and shifts to right after acclimatization). Increased erythropoietin secretion causing an increasing shift in the number of circulating red blood cells Increased number of mitochondria to provide more energy Increased myoglobin to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues Increased tissue cytochrome oxidase Increased sympathetic tone

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B - Pulmonary vasoconstriction occurs due to the lack of smooth muscles in the pulmonary arteries in response to hypoxia Option A - Polycythemia - Erythropoietin secretion increases on the ascent to high altitude which results in polycythemia Option C - Total barometric pressure decreases as altitude increases, resulting in decreased Po 2 (partial pressure of oxygen) leading to hypoxic hypoxia.
